content.text: To establish a systematic, data-driven, and collaborative process for continuous school improvement that aligns with the Eduversal vision, enhances student outcomes, meets accreditation standards, and fosters a culture of reflective practice among all stakeholders.

subsections.title: The Eduversal School Improvement Cycle (P.I.E. Model)

content.text: Eduversal schools utilize the P.I.E. (Plan, Implement, Evaluate) model, a cyclical framework for continuous improvement. This iterative process ensures that school development is strategic, evidence-based, and responsive to the evolving needs of the school community.

items.title: PLAN (Where are we now & Where are we going?)
points: Conduct a comprehensive self-assessment and data analysis.
Identify key priorities and root causes of challenges.
Set 3-5 SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound) goals.
Develop a detailed School Improvement Plan (SIP) outlining actions, responsibilities, and timelines.

items.title: IMPLEMENT (How will we get there?)
points: Execute the strategies and actions defined in the SIP.
Provide necessary resources and professional development.
Monitor implementation fidelity through regular check-ins and classroom walkthroughs.

items.title: EVALUATE (How did we do & What's next?)
points: Collect and analyze data to measure progress against KPIs.
Evaluate the impact of implemented strategies.
Celebrate successes and identify lessons learned.
Use findings to inform the next planning cycle.

content.text: The foundation of any effective improvement plan is a deep and honest understanding of the school's current reality. This phase involves gathering and analyzing a wide range of quantitative and qualitative data.

items: Student Achievement Data: EASE results, Cambridge exam scores, ANBK national assessment data, internal assessment results.
Stakeholder Feedback: Student, parent, and staff satisfaction surveys.
Appraisal & Observation Data: Eduversal appraisal reports, internal classroom observation summaries.
School Operations Data: Student attendance and behavior records, teacher retention rates, enrollment trends.
Data Triangulation: Cross-reference multiple data sources to validate findings.
SWOT Analysis: Identify internal Strengths and Weaknesses, and external Opportunities and Threats.
Root Cause Analysis: Use techniques like the '5 Whys' to move beyond symptoms and identify the underlying causes of challenges.

content.text: Based on the data analysis, the school leadership team, in consultation with the community, identifies 3-5 high-leverage priority areas for the academic year. For each priority, a SMART goal is developed.

content.title: Example SMART Goal
content.text: By the end of the 2025-2026 academic year, increase the percentage of Grade 10 students achieving A*-C in IGCSE Mathematics from 65% to 75% by implementing targeted intervention strategies and improving formative assessment practices.

content.title: Key Performance Indicators (KPIs)
content.text: KPIs are the specific, measurable metrics used to track progress toward a goal. Each goal should have 2-3 leading and lagging KPIs.

items: Leading Indicators: Measure activities and processes that are expected to lead to the desired outcome (e.g., '% of math teachers using formative assessment daily').
Lagging Indicators: Measure the final outcome (e.g., 'Final IGCSE Math A*-C percentage').

content.text: The School Improvement Plan (SIP) is the formal, documented action plan that outlines how the school will achieve its strategic goals. It is a living document, reviewed and updated regularly.

content.title: SIP Template Components
rows: The overarching SMART goal for the year.
Why this goal is a priority, supported by data from the self-assessment.
Specific, concrete steps that will be taken to achieve the goal.
The individual or team accountable for leading each action.
Start and end dates for each action.
Budget, materials, training, or support required.
How progress and success will be measured (leading and lagging indicators).
What artifacts will be collected to demonstrate completion and impact.

content.title: Implementation & Monitoring
content.text: A plan is only as good as its execution. Regular monitoring ensures the SIP stays on track.

items: Monthly SIP Review: Leadership team meets to review progress on all actions and KPIs.
Classroom Walkthroughs: Principals and HODs conduct frequent, informal observations to see strategies in action.
Data Dashboards: Key data is updated and reviewed regularly to track leading indicators.

content.title: Evaluation & Annual Review
content.text: At the end of the academic year, the school conducts a formal evaluation of the SIP.

items: Final Data Analysis: Compare end-of-year data against baseline data and KPIs.
Impact Assessment: Determine which actions had the most significant positive impact.
Lessons Learned: Analyze what worked, what didn't, and why.
Annual Report: A summary of the year's improvement journey is shared with the school community.
Input for Next Cycle: The evaluation findings become a key data source for the next year's P.I.E. cycle.

content.text: To demonstrate a robust school improvement process, schools should maintain the following documentation:

items: The official School Improvement Plan (SIP) for the current academic year.
Data analysis summaries (e.g., SWOT analysis, survey result summaries).
Meeting minutes from leadership and department data reviews.
KPI dashboards or progress tracking spreadsheets.
End-of-Year School Improvement Report.
Examples of how data analysis has led to specific changes in teaching practice or school policy.
CIS Standards: Domain A (Purpose and Direction) and Domain H (Continuous Improvement).
WASC Category A: Organization for Student Learning, and Category D: Resource Management and Development.
Indonesian National Standards for Education (SNP): Standard 4 (Process Standard) and Standard 5 (Assessment Standard).
Eduversal's commitment to data-informed decision-making and excellence as outlined in the Governance Charter (Section 1).
